40|finger fist the choice decimal binary representation the binary number system offer many advantage over decimal representation for high performance general purpose computer the greater simplicity binary arithmetic unit and the greater compactness binary number both contribute directly arithmetic speed obvious and perhaps more important the way binary addressing and instruction format can increase the overall performance binary address are also essential certain powerful operation which are not practical with decimal instruction format the other hand decimal number are essential for communicating between man and the computer application requiring the processing large volume inherently decimal input and output data the time for decimal binary conversion needed purely binary computer may significant slower decimal adder may take time than fast binary adder doing addition and two conversion careful review the significance decimal and binary addressing and both binary and decimal data arithmetic supplemented efficient conversion instruction |

243|dimensional code for detecting and correcting multiple error the paper introduces new family code for detecting and correcting multiple error binary coded message the message itself arranged conceptually into multidimensional rectangular array the process encoding and error detection are based upon parity evaluation along prescribed dimension the array effectiveness the code increased introducing system check bit which essentially parity check the other parity bit only three dimensional code are discussed this paper with parity evaluation along the horizontal the vertical and one main diagonal however the family code not restricted three dimension evidenced the discussion minnick and ashenhurst similar multidimensional single bit selection plan used for another purpose four dimensional code correcting three and detecting four error been developed the extension higher dimensional code with greater correction power straightforward |

1936|variable length tree structure having minimum average search time sussenguth suggests paper that file should organized doubly chained tree structure necessary both search and update frequently such structure provides compromise between the fast searchslow update characteristic binary searching and the slow searchfast update characteristic serial searching his method however contains the limiting restriction that all terminal node lie the same level the tree this paper considers the effect relaxing this restriction first tree which have the property that priori the filial set each node well defined are studied proved that coding the node within each filial set with respect the number terminal node reachable from each necessary and sufficient guarantee minimum average search time then the more general case that where the entire structure the tree changeable treated procedure developed for constructing tree with minimum average search time simple closed expression for this minimum average search time obtained function the number terminal node the storage capacity required implement the doubly chained tree structure digital computer also determined finally the total cost the structure using sussenguths cost criterion computed shown that significant improvement both the average search time and the total cost can obtained relaxing sussenguths restriction that all terminal node lie the same level the tree |

2263|the conversion limited entry decision table optimal and near optimal flowchart two new algorithm two new algorithm for deriving optimal and near optimal flowchart from limited entry decision table are presented both take into account rule frequency and the time needed test condition one the algorithm called the optimum finding algorithm lead flowchart which truly minimizes execution time for decision table which simple rule are already contracted complex rule the other one called the optimum approaching algorithm requires many fewer calculation but doe not necessarily produce the optimum flowchart the algorithm are first derived for treating decision table not containing else rule but the optimum approaching algorithm shown equally valid for table including such rule both algorithm are compared with existing one and are applied somewhat large decision table derived from real case from this comparison two conclusion are drawn the optimum approaching algorithm will usually lead better result than comparable existing one and will not require more but usually computation time general the greater computation effort needed for applying the optimum finding algorithm will not justified the small reduction execution time obtained |
